sen.j: 東山（ひがしやま）は京都盆地の東側にある山の総称である。
sen.e: Higashiyama is a collective name referring to the mountains on the east side of Kyoto Basin.
Higashiyama is a collective name referring to the mountains on the east side of Kyoto Basin.
Higashiyama is a collective name referring to the mountains on the east side of Kyoto Basin.

sen.j: またその山麓の地域を指すこともある。
sen.e: Also, the name sometimes refers to the region on the foot of the mountains.
Also, the name sometimes refers to the region on the foot of the mountains.
Also, the name sometimes refers to the region on the foot of the mountains.

sen.j: 北は比叡山（京都市左京区、滋賀県大津市）から南は稲荷山（京都市伏見区）までとするのが一般的である。
sen.e: Generally, Higashiyama is defined as the area from Mt. Hiei in the north (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City and Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) to Mt. Inari in the south (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City).
Generally, Higashiyama is defined as the area from Mt. Hiei in the north (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City and Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) to Mt. Inari in the south (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City).
Generally, Higashiyama is defined as the area from Mt. Hiei in the north (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City and Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) to Mt. Inari in the south (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: 狭義には、比叡山を含めず山中越の南の大文字山（京都市左京区）から南を指すこともある。
sen.e: In a narrower sense, it may refer to the southern area of Mt. Daimonji (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) to the south of Yamanakagoe, a main road called Shimogamo-Otsu Line today, excluding Mt. Hiei.
In a narrower sense, it may refer to the southern area of Mt. Daimonji (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) to the south of Yamanakagoe (a main road called Shimogamo-Otsu Line toda), excluding Mt. Hiei.
In a narrower sense, it may refer to the southern area of Mt. Daimonji (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City) to the south of Yamanakagoe (a main road called Shimogamo-Otsu Line toda), excluding Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: 「東山」とは一つの山系の名ではなく、京都の中心部から見て東に見える山を指す。
sen.e: "Higashiyama" means the mountains that can be viewed in the east from the central Kyoto, not a name of specific mountain range.
"Higashiyama" means the mountains that can be viewed in the east from the central Kyoto, not a name of specific mountain range.
"Higashiyama" means the mountains that can be viewed in the east from the central Kyoto, not a name of specific mountain range.

sen.j: したがって、他の山と鹿ヶ谷で隔てられている吉田山が含まれる一方、比叡山の北に連なる比良山系の山は含まれない。
sen.e: Thus, while Mt. Yoshida, separated by Shishigatani from other mountains, is included in Higashiyama, mountains of the Hira mountain range, located to the north of Mt. Hiei, is not.
Thus, while Mt. Yoshida, separated by Shishigatani from other mountains, is included in Higashiyama, mountains of the Hira mountain range system, located to the north of Mt. Hiei, is not.
Thus, while Mt. Yoshida, separated by Shishigatani from other mountains, is included in Higashiyama, mountains of the Hira mountain range system, located to the north of Mt. Hiei, is not.

sen.j: また大文字山の東にあり京都市街地から頂を確認することが難しい如意ヶ岳も含まれないことが多い。
sen.e: Similarly, it often excludes Mt. Nyoigadake to the east of Mt. Daimonji, whose top is hard to be identified from the central Kyoto.
Similarly, it often excludes Mt. Nyoigadake to the east of Mt. Daimonji, whose top is hard to be identified from the central Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Similarly, it often excludes Mt. Nyoigadake to the east of Mt. Daimonji, whose top is hard to be identified from the central Kyoto.

sen.j: 「東山」の呼称は古くは平安時代にも用いられたことがあるが、一般的になったのは室町時代以降である。
sen.e: Although the name "Higashiyama" had been used in ancient time of the Heian era, it became popular since the Muromachi period.
Although the name 'Higashiyama' had been used in ancient time of the Heian period, it became popular since the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 表記、用語を変えました。
sen.e: Although the name 'Higashiyama' had been used in ancient time of the Heian period, it became popular since the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 北から順に記す。
sen.e: Main mountains are listed below from the northernmost one.
Major mountains are listed below from the northernmost one.
Major mountains are listed below from the northernmost one.

sen.j: なお一つの山が複数の名をもつことがある。
sen.e: Note that one mountain can have several names.
Note that one mountain can have several names.
Note that one mountain can have several names.

sen.j: また一つの山名が場合により異なる山を指すこともある。
sen.e: Also, in some cases, the same mountain name may refer to a different mountain.
Also, in some cases, the same mountain name may refer to a different mountain.

sen.j: 如意ヶ岳としばしば混同されるが、別の山である。

sen.j: ただし古くは大文字山のことを如意ヶ岳とも呼んだ。

sen.j: 東山の山々を総称して、「東山三十六峰」（ひがしやまさんじゅうろっぽう）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Mountains included in Higashiyama are often collectively called as "Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo (thirty-six) mountain range."
Mountains in Higashiyama are often collectively called as 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' (36 mountain range).
Mountains in Higashiyama are often collectively called as 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' (36 mountain range).

sen.j: 言葉の成立当初は、具体的に36の峰を擁するという意味ではなく、なだらかに連なる東山の山々を洛中から見て、おおよそ三十六ほどは連なっていようかと例えられたものであろう。
sen.e: When the name was first invented, it apparently did not point to the specific 36 mountains, but just expressed an impression that there were a chain of gently sloping mountains in the east viewed from the Rakuchu (inside the capital Kyoto), which could be seen as roughly 36 of them.

When the name was first invented, it apparently did not point to the specific 36 mountains, but just expressed an impression that there were a chain of gently sloping mountains in the east viewed from the Rakuchu (inside the capital Kyoto), which could be seen as roughly 36 of them.

When the name was first invented, it apparently did not point to the specific 36 mountains, but just expressed an impression that there were a chain of gently sloping mountains in the east viewed from the Rakuchu (inside the capital Kyoto), which could be seen as roughly 36 of them.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の学者であり、東山の景観を好んだことで知られる頼山陽が、自らを「三十六峯外史」と号していたことからも、江戸時代頃には「三十六峰」の考えが知られていたものと推測される。
sen.e: The fact that Sanyo RAI, a scholar of the late Edo period, who was well-known for his fondness for the landscape of Higashiyama, called himself "Sanju-Roppo Gaishi" implies that the notion of "Sanju-Roppo" presumably became common around the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「三十六峯外史」: 「外史」の適訳が見つからず、ローマ字表記のままとなりました。
sen.e: The fact that Sanyo RAI, a scholar of the late Edo period, who was well-known for his fondness for the landscape of Higashiyama, called himself 'Sanju-Roppo Gaishi' implies that the notion of 'Sanju-Roppo' presumably became common around the Edo period.

The fact that Sanyo RAI, a scholar of the late Edo period, who was well-known for his fondness for the landscape of Higashiyama, called himself 'Sanju-Roppo Gaishi' implies that the notion of 'Sanju-Roppo' presumably became common around the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代末期の「花洛名勝圖會」では、「東山三十六峰」の言葉を見ることができ、これが「東山三十六峰」という言葉を記した、現存する史料としては最古のものとされる。
sen.e: The word "Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo" can be found in "Karaku meisho zue"(a guidebook on some scenic beauty) compiled in the end of Edo period, which was apparently the oldest material that exists today denoting that word.

The word 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' can be found in 'Karaku meisho zue' (a guidebook on some scenic beauty) compiled in the end of Edo period, which was apparently the oldest material that exists today denoting that word.

The word 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' can be found in 'Karaku meisho zue' (a guidebook on some scenic beauty) compiled in the end of Edo period, which was apparently the oldest material that exists today denoting that word.

sen.j: この「花洛名勝圖會」には、「どの山々を指して三十六の峰と言っているのかは明らかではない」といった記述があり、「三十六峰」が具体的にどの山々を指しているのかまでは特定されていなかったようだ。
sen.e: This "Karaku meisho zue" states that "the exact names of those thirty-six mountains are unclear", indicating that the "Sanju-Roppo" did not actually point to the specific mountains.
This 'Karaku meisho zue' states that 'the exact names of those 36 mountains are unclear,' indicating that the 'Sanju-Roppo' did not actually point to the specific mountains.
This 'Karaku meisho zue' states that 'the exact names of those 36 mountains are unclear,' indicating that the 'Sanju-Roppo' did not actually point to the specific mountains.

sen.j: 前述の通り、江戸時代以前には、「三十六峰」は具体的には特定されていなかったと考えられるが、近代以降、「三十六峰」を具体的に特定しようという試みも行われている。
sen.e: As mentioned above, before the Edo period it was generally believed that the "Sanju-Roppo" were not specifically identified, however, there have been several attempts to identify them after the end of Edo period.

As mentioned above, before the Edo period it was generally believed that the 'Sanju-Roppo' were not specifically identified, however, there have been several attempts to identify them after the end of Edo period.

As mentioned above, before the Edo period it was generally believed that the 'Sanju-Roppo' were not specifically identified, however, there have been several attempts to identify them after the end of Edo period.

sen.j: 1936年の大阪営林局「東山国有林風致計画」においては、「東山三十六峰」の山名が具体的に記述されているが、これが、三十六の山名を羅列した史料としては、ほぼ最古のものであるとされる。
sen.e: The specific mountain names of "Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo" were stated in "Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning" compiled by Osaka District Forestry Office in 1936, which is regarded as an almost oldest material listing the specific 36 mountain names.
sen.cmt: 「東山国有林風致計画」:定訳不明です。
sen.e: The specific mountain names of 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' were stated in 'Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning' compiled by Osaka District Forestry Office in 1936, which is regarded as an almost oldest material listing the specific 36 mountain names.
sen.cmt: スペース削除などしました。
sen.e: The specific mountain names of 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' were stated in 'Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning' compiled by Osaka District Forestry Office in 1936, which is regarded as an almost oldest material listing the specific 36 mountain names.

sen.j: しかし、ここで名前の挙げられている山名は、江戸時代前期に記された「雍州府志」における「山川門」の記述を踏襲したものにすぎず、実状にそぐわないものも少なくなかった。
sen.e: However, the mountain names listed here were just copied from statements of "Yamakawamon" in "Yoshufushi" (a geographical description of Yamashiro province), compiled before the Edo period, thus many of those names are inconsistent with the reality.

However, the mountain names listed here were just copied from statements of 'Yamakawamon' in 'Yoshufushi' (a geographical description of Yamashiro Province), compiled in the early Edo period, thus many of those names are inconsistent with the reality.

However, the mountain names listed here were just copied from statements of 'Yamakawamon' in 'Yoshufushi' (a geographical description of Yamashiro Province), compiled in the early Edo period, thus many of those names are inconsistent with the reality.

sen.j: その後、1956年の京都新聞において、「三十六峰」を具体的に特定した記事が連載されることとなった。
sen.e: Subsequently, an article identifying the 36 mountains was serialized in "Kyoto Shimbun" newspaper in 1956.
Subsequently, an article identifying 'the 36 mountains' was serialized in Kyoto Shinbun Newspaper in 1956.
Subsequently, an article identifying 'the 36 mountains' was serialized in Kyoto Shinbun Newspaper in 1956.

sen.j: 以降に刊行された書籍などでは、この連載記事により選定された「三十六峰」をもって「東山三十六峰」とすることが多い。
sen.e: Since then, in many cases, publications including books would assume the 36 mountains selected by this article as "Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo".
Since then, in many cases, publications including books would assume 'the 36 mountains' selected by this article as 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo.'
Since then, in many cases, publications including books would assume 'the 36 mountains' selected by this article as 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo.'

sen.j: 「東山国有林風致計画」の選定、京都新聞の連載記事による選定では、両者で一部異なった山の名前が挙げられており、また、現在では「山」と呼ぶに値する頂の確認できないものもある。
sen.e: The respective selections of 36 mountains by "Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning" and the article of Kyoto Shimbun were partly inconsistent, and today, some of those mountains cannot be confirmed to have enough height of peaks deserved to be called "a mountain."

The respective selections of 36 mountains by 'Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning' and the article of Kyoto Shinbun Newspaper were partly inconsistent, and today, some of those mountains cannot be confirmed to have enough height of peaks deserved to be called 'a mountain.'

The respective selections of 36 mountains by 'Higashiyama National Forest Landscape Management Planning' and the article of Kyoto Shinbun Newspaper were partly inconsistent, and today, some of those mountains cannot be confirmed to have enough height of peaks deserved to be called 'a mountain.'

sen.j: 「東山三十六峰」という呼称を使う場合、山科盆地からは確認できるが、京都市街地から頂を確認することが難しい花山、六条山といった山は三十六の峰に含まれないことに留意。
sen.e: Note that the name "Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo"does not include such mountains as Mt. Kazan and Mt. Rokujo, which are able to confirm from Yamashina Basin, but are difficult to identify their peaks from Kyoto city urban area.

Note that the name 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' does not include such mountains as Mt. Kazan and Mt. Rokujo, which are able to confirm from Yamashina Basin, but are difficult to identify their peaks from Kyoto City urban area.

Note that the name 'Higashiyama Sanju-Roppo' does not include such mountains as Mt. Kazan and Mt. Rokujo, which are able to confirm from Yamashina Basin, but are difficult to identify their peaks from Kyoto City urban area.

sen.j: 東山は花折断層、鹿ヶ谷断層、桃山断層などの断層の活動により隆起してできた山である。
sen.e: Higashiyama mountains had been formed by upheavals due to activities of some faults including Hanaori Fault, Shishigatani Fault, and Momoyama Fault.
Higashiyama mountains had been formed by upheavals due to activities of some faults including Hanaori Fault, Shishigatani Fault, and Momoyama Fault.
Higashiyama mountains had been formed by upheavals due to activities of some faults including Hanaori Fault, Shishigatani Fault, and Momoyama Fault.

sen.j: 浸食が進んでおり、明確な頂上をもたない山が多い。
sen.e: Many mountains do not have definitive mountaintops due to ongoing erosion.
Many mountains do not have definitive mountaintops due to ongoing erosion.
Many mountains do not have definitive mountaintops due to ongoing erosion.

sen.j: また西側の麓には扇状地が形成されている。
sen.e: Also, an alluvial fan was formed on the western base.
Also, an alluvial fan was formed on the western base.
Also, an alluvial fan was formed on the western base.

sen.j: 山体は主に堆積岩からなるが、比叡山と大文字山の間の京都府道・滋賀県道30号下鴨大津線付近では花崗岩が貫入している。
sen.e: Although the body of the mountains mainly consist of sedimentary rocks, granite intrusions can be found in areas around Kyoto/Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line between Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji.

Although the body of the mountains mainly consist of sedimentary rocks, granite intrusions can be found in areas around Kyoto and Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line between Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji.

Although the body of the mountains mainly consist of sedimentary rocks, granite intrusions can be found in areas around Kyoto and Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line between Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji.

sen.j: この貫入により、その両側の比叡山と大文字山の山頂付近は変成岩のホルンフェルスとなった。
sen.e: Due to this intrusion, the soil around the peaks of Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji on both sides of Shimogamo-Otsu Line has transformed into metamorphic rocks, or hornfels.
Due to this intrusion, the soil around the peaks of Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji on both sides of the road has transformed into metamorphic rocks, or hornfels.
Due to this intrusion, the soil around the peaks of Mt. Hiei and Mt. Daimonji on both sides of the road has transformed into metamorphic rocks, or hornfels.

sen.j: ホルンフェルスは硬く風化しにくいため、これらの山は東山の中でも高く目立っている。
sen.e: Since hornfels are rigid and resistant to weathering, these two mountains are higher than other Higashiyama mountains and thus conspicuous.
Since hornfels are rigid and resistant to weathering, these two mountains are higher than other Higashiyama mountains and thus conspicuous.
Since hornfels are rigid and resistant to weathering, these two mountains are higher than other Higashiyama mountains and thus conspicuous.

sen.j: また山中越の峠から発する白川 (淀川水系)は、花崗岩が風化してできた白砂によって白く見えるためこの名がついた。
sen.e: Also, Shirakawa River (Yodogawa river system) flowing from the mountain pass of Yamanakagoe was so named, meaning a white river, because white sands of weathered granite make the river look white.

Also, the Shira-kawa River (the Yodo-gawa River system) flowing from the mountain pass of Yamanakagoe was so named, meaning a white river, because white sands of weathered granite make the river look white.

Also, the Shira-kawa River (the Yodo-gawa River system) flowing from the mountain pass of Yamanakagoe was so named, meaning a white river, because white sands of weathered granite make the river look white.

tit.e: The Foot and Top of Mountains

sen.j: 東山の山麓には多くの神社・寺院がある。
sen.e: There are numerous shrines and temples at the foot of Higashiyama mountain range.
There are numerous shrines and temples at the foot of Higashiyama mountain range.
There are numerous shrines and temples at the foot of Higashiyama mountain range.

sen.j: その中には伏見稲荷大社、清水寺のように平安京よりも古い歴史をもつものもある。
sen.e: Among them are Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine and Kiyomizu-dera Temple, both of which have older history than Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).
Among them are Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine and Kiyomizu-dera Temple, both of which have older history than Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).
Among them are Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine and Kiyomizu-dera Temple, both of which have older history than Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

sen.j: また山麓は平安時代から近代にかけて、京都の皇族・貴族や武士の保養地であった。
sen.e: Also, this area on the foot of the mountains were health resort catering to the Imperial family, nobility and samurai in Kyoto from the Heian period to the modern times.
Also, this area on the foot of the mountains were health resort catering to the Imperial family, nobility and samurai in Kyoto from the Heian period to the modern times.
Also, this area on the foot of the mountains were health resort catering to the Imperial family, nobility and samurai in Kyoto from the Heian period to the modern times.

sen.j: 特に足利義政の東山山荘（現慈照寺、通称銀閣寺）は有名である。
sen.e: The Higashiyama mountain villa of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA is especially famous (present Jisho-ji Temple, aka. Ginkaku-ji Temple).
The Higashiyama mountain villa of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA is especially famous (present Jisho-ji Temple, aka. Ginkaku-ji Temple).
The Higashiyama mountain villa of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA is especially famous (present Jisho-ji Temple, aka. Ginkaku-ji Temple).

sen.j: 現代ではこれらの寺社・庭園が、東山の景観とともに観光客の人気を集めている。
sen.e: Today, in addition to the scenic beauty of Higashiyama mountain range, these temples and shrines with their gardens have become popular tourist spots.
Today, in addition to the scenic beauty of Higashiyama mountain range, these temples and shrines with their gardens have become popular tourist spots.

sen.j: 京都から東の山科盆地・近江盆地方面へ向かうには東山を越えなければならない。
sen.e: In order to head to Yamashina Basin and Omi Basin district to the east of Kyoto, one has to cross over Higashiyama mountain range.
In order to head to Yamashina Basin and Omi Basin district to the east of Kyoto, one has to cross over Higashiyama mountain range.
In order to head to Yamashina Basin and Omi Basin district to the east of Kyoto, one has to cross over Higashiyama mountain range.

sen.j: これには以下のようなルートがある。
sen.e: Available routes are as follows:
Available routes are as follows:
Available routes are as follows:

sen.j: 山中越
sen.e: Yamanakagoe
Yamanakagoe
Yamanakagoe

sen.j: 左京区北白川から、瓜生山と大文字山の間の山中越を経て、大津市の志賀に至る。
sen.e: Yamanakagoe, passing through between Mt. Uryu and Mt. Daimonji, runs from Kita-shirakawa, Sakyo Ward to Shiga, Otsu City.
Yamanakagoe, passing through between Mt. Uryu and Mt. Daimonji, runs from Kita-shirakawa, Sakyo Ward to Shiga, Otsu City.
Yamanakagoe, passing through between Mt. Uryu and Mt. Daimonji, runs from Kita-shirakawa, Sakyo Ward to Shiga, Otsu City.

sen.j: 京都府道・滋賀県道30号下鴨大津線。
sen.e: Kyoto/Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line.
Kyoto and Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line.
Kyoto and Shiga Prefectural Road 30 Shimogamo-Otsu Line.

sen.j: 志賀越の道とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: This is also called "Shigagoemichi."
This is also called Shigagoe no michi.
This is also called Shigagoe no michi.

sen.j: 途中に比叡平の住宅地があり、比叡山頂に向かう比叡山ドライブウェイが分岐する。
sen.e: There are residential areas at Hieidaira along the road, which branches into Hieizan Driveway heading toward the top of Mt. Hiei.
There are residential areas at Hieidaira along the road, which branches into Hieizan Driveway heading toward the top of Mt. Hiei.
There are residential areas at Hieidaira along the road, which branches into Hieizan Driveway heading toward the top of Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: 日ノ岡越
sen.e: Hinookagoe
Hinookagoe
Hinookagoe

sen.j: 東山区粟田口（蹴上）から、日ノ岡を経て山科区御陵に至る。
sen.e: A road runs from Awataguchi (Keage), Higashiyama Ward via Hinooka to Misasagi, Yamashina Ward.
A road runs from Awataguchi (Keage), Higashiyama Ward via Hinooka to Misasagi, Yamashina Ward.
A road runs from Awataguchi (Keage), Higashiyama Ward via Hinooka to Misasagi, Yamashina Ward.

sen.j: 京都府道143号四ノ宮四ツ塚線。
sen.e: Kyoto prefectural road No.143 Shinomiya Yotsuzuka Route.
Kyoto Prefectural Road 143 Shinomiya-Yotsuzuka Line.
Kyoto Prefectural Road 143 Shinomiya-Yotsuzuka Line.

sen.j: 旧東海道（現三条通）であり、地下を京都市営地下鉄東西線が通る。
sen.e: This is Old Tokaido Road (present Sanjo-dori Street), under which Kyoto City Subway Tozai Line runs.
This is old Tokaido Road (present Sanjo-dori Street), under which Kyoto City Subway Tozai Line runs.
This is old Tokaido Road (present Sanjo-dori Street), under which Kyoto City Subway Tozai Line runs.

sen.j: かつては京阪京津線が三条通の路上（峠の部分は三条通に接した南側の専用軌道上）を走っていた。
sen.e: In the past, Keihan Keishin Line ran on Sanjo-dori Street (for the part of mountain pass, a special track on the southern side adjacent to Sanjo-dori Street was used).
In the past, Keihan Keishin Line ran on Sanjo-dori Street (for the part of mountain pass, a special track on the southern side adjacent to Sanjo-dori Street was used).
In the past, Keihan Keishin Line ran on Sanjo-dori Street (for the part of mountain pass, a special track on the southern side adjacent to Sanjo-dori Street was used).

sen.j: また琵琶湖疏水もほぼこのルートに沿っている。
sen.e: The Lake Biwa Canal also goes along this route.
The Lake Biwa Canal also goes along this route.
The Lake Biwa Canal also goes along this route.

sen.j: 東山トンネル
sen.e: Higashiyama Tunnel
Higashiyama Tunnel
Higashiyama Tunnel

sen.j: 国道1号（五条通）、東海道本線、東海道新幹線はいずれも東山区南部からトンネルで東山を抜ける。
sen.e: National Route 1(Gojo-dori Street), Tokaido Main Line, and Tokaido Shinkansen all go through Higashiyama via tunnels from southern part of Higashiyama Ward.
National Route 1 (Gojo-dori Street), Tokaido Main Line, and Tokaido Shinkansen all go through Higashiyama via tunnels from southern part of Higashiyama Ward.
sen.cmt: スペース補足しました。
sen.e: National Route 1 (Gojo-dori Street), Tokaido Main Line, and Tokaido Shinkansen all go through Higashiyama via tunnels from southern part of Higashiyama Ward.

sen.j: トンネルの名はすべて「東山トンネル」である。
sen.e: The name of those tunnels are all "Higashiyama Tunnel."
The name of those tunnels are all 'Higashiyama Tunnel.'
The name of those tunnels are all 'Higashiyama Tunnel.'

sen.j: 国道1号東山トンネルは渋谷街道（京都府道116号渋谷山科停車場線）と重複している。
sen.e: The National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel overlaps with Shibutani-kaido Road (Kyoto Prefectural Road 116 Shibutani-Yamashina Teishajo Line).
The National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel overlaps with Shibutani-kaido Road (Kyoto Prefectural Road 116 Shibutani-Yamashina Teishajo Line).
The National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel overlaps with Shibutani-kaido Road (Kyoto Prefectural Road 116 Shibutani-Yamashina Teishajo Line).

sen.j: 国道1号東山トンネルの北側にある歩行者用トンネルがかつての渋谷街道のトンネル（花山トンネル）である。
sen.e: The pedestrian tunnel to the north of National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel is former Shibutani-kaido Tunnel (Kazan Tunnel).
The pedestrian tunnel to the north of National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel is former Shibutani-kaido Tunnel (also known as Kazan Tunnel).
The pedestrian tunnel to the north of National Route 1 Higashiyama Tunnel is former Shibutani-kaido Tunnel (also known as Kazan Tunnel).

sen.j: 滑石越
sen.e: Suberi-ishi-goe
Suberiishigoe
Suberiishigoe

sen.j: 東山区今熊野から南東方向に東山を越えて山科区西野山に至る。
sen.e: This road runs from Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward toward southeast over Higashiyama to Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.
This road runs from Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward toward southeast over Higashiyama to Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.
This road runs from Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward toward southeast over Higashiyama to Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.

sen.j: 京都府道118号勧修寺今熊野線。
sen.e: Kyoto Prefectural Road 118 Kanshuji Imagumano Line.
Kyoto Prefectural Road 118 Kanshuji-Imagumano Line.
Kyoto Prefectural Road 118 Kanshuji-Imagumano Line.

sen.j: 醍醐道とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called "Daigodo."
It is also called Daigodo.
It is also called Daigodo.

sen.j: 極めて細い道である。
sen.e: A very narrow road.
A very narrow road.
A very narrow road.

sen.j: 稲荷山トンネル
sen.e: Inariyama Tunnel
Inariyama Tunnel
Inariyama Tunnel

sen.j: 伏見区深草の鴨川東出入口から、稲荷山トンネル (京都府)を経て山科区西野山の山科出入口に至る。
sen.e: This route runs from Kamogawa Higashi Deiriguchi Half-interchange in Fukakusa, Fushimi Ward via Inariyama Tunnel (Kyoto Prefecture) to Yamashina Deiriguchi Half-interchange in Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.
This route runs from Kamogawa Higashi Interchange in Fukakusa, Fushimi Ward via Inariyama Tunnel (Kyoto Prefecture) to Yamashina Interchange in Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.
sen.cmt: 用語表現を変えました。
sen.e: This route runs from Kamogawa Higashi Interchange in Fukakusa, Fushimi Ward via Inariyama Tunnel (Kyoto Prefecture) to Yamashina Interchange in Nishinoyama, Yamashina Ward.

sen.j: 阪神高速8号京都線（新十条通）の一部である。
sen.e: This is a part of Hanshin Expressway No. 8 Kyoto Route (Shin-Jujo-dori Route).
This is a part of Hanshin Expressway 8 Kyoto Line (Shinjujo-dori Street).
This is a part of Hanshin Expressway 8 Kyoto Line (Shinjujo-dori Street).

sen.j: 大岩街道
sen.e: Oiwa-kaido Road
Oiwa-kaido Road
Oiwa-kaido Road

sen.j: 名神高速道路は稲荷山の南、大岩街道（滋賀県道・京都府道35号大津淀線）を通って山科盆地に入っている。
sen.e: Meishin Expressway runs through Oiwa-kaido Road (Shiga/Kyoto Prefectural Road 35 Otsu-Yodo Line) to the south of Mt. Inari to enter Yamashina Basin.
Meishin Expressway runs through Oiwa-kaido Road (Shiga and Kyoto Prefectural Road 35 Otsu-Yodo Line) to the south of Mt. Inari to enter Yamashina Basin.
Meishin Expressway runs through Oiwa-kaido Road (Shiga and Kyoto Prefectural Road 35 Otsu-Yodo Line) to the south of Mt. Inari to enter Yamashina Basin.

sen.j: このルートは、伏見街道（または大津街道）の一部である。
sen.e: This route is a part of Fushimi-kaido Road (or Otsu-kaido Road).
This route is a part of Fushimi-kaido Road (or Otsu-kaido Road).
This route is a part of Fushimi-kaido Road (or Otsu-kaido Road).

sen.j: また東山トンネル開通前の東海道本線はこのルートを迂回していた。
sen.e: Before Higashiyama tunnel opened, Tokaido Main Line had bypassed this route.
Before Higashiyama Tunnel opened, Tokaido Main Line ran this route.
Before Higashiyama Tunnel opened, Tokaido Main Line ran this route.
